intro: Bupleurum pamiricum, commonly known as the Pamir angelica, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in high-altitude environments and is adapted to cold, arid conditions. Bupleurum pamiricum is often found in rocky soils and is valued for its medicinal properties in traditional medicine.
